Description: Body sherd of North Ionian black-figured pottery open vessel, probably a column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of part of legs of two warriors moving left (added red on greaves and part of shield rim of left-hand warrior, merely lower part of advanced leg with part of greave, and part of other foot of second warrior remaining, together with spear presumably held in hand, with added red, pointing diagonally down to left; below, red band on reserved background and another over top black zone on lower body.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 275, no. B225 bis) ((published as Attic))
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.314)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
